title: Accardo
author: Accardo
content: Meitu a Chinese selfie app developer  has sold all his bitcoin after investing over $100 million in Bitcoin and Eth. Which earned him the title "Asian Microstrategy". The company held for  3 years and decided to liquidate their coins, and made an extra profit of $180 million, from both Eth and BTC. However, such profits would interest some companies to sell their holdings, due to their motive of investment. Hence, investors who may not wait or hold more longer after the massive increase in Bitcoin may begin the bear season.

However, such profits would interest some companies to sell their holdings, due to their motive of investment. Hence, investors who may not wait or hold more longer after the massive increase in Bitcoin may begin the bear season.People can call Meitu as an "Asian Microstrategy" but in fact they're not Microstrategy, never. Their approach can be different than Microstrategy too, and because they're a considerable smaller institutional investor than Microstrategy, their sale is not a big bomb with enough pressure to dump Bitcoin market.Do they have rights to sell bitcoins that were bought as their investment?They've full rights to do that, and it's good for any investor who was able to take profit and cash out. If Bitcoin blockchain and Bitcoin market become something that does not allow investors free rights to cash out anytime they want, it's no longer a good blockchain to use and to invest money in.

However, such profits would interest some companies to sell their holdings, due to their motive of investment. Hence, investors who may not wait or hold more longer after the massive increase in Bitcoin may begin the bear season.I guess this gives us a glimpse that just because a company is vocal about accumulating Bitcoin and even says "HODL," we shouldn’t trust them blindly. Being a business entity, their main motivation is always profit. It’s basic - they’ll only make a profit once they sell.So, I wouldn’t be surprised if MicroStrategy (the non-Asian one) sells their holdings in the future. They’re probably waiting for a bigger profit, and they’re definitely not selling at $100k, as that milestone has already been achieved.

comments.author: Ziskinberg
comments.body: If it’s the same concept as MicroStrategy, then selling is to be expected. you now, shareholders don’t buy shares for nothing, they’re looking to see the shares increase in value so they can sell and make a profit. That can only happen if the price of Bitcoin goes up.The same applies to Michael Saylor’s business. It’s his responsibility to ensure that shareholders gain profit when the time comes to sell. At the moment, they probably don’t see it as the right time to sell, so they’ll likely continue accumulating, of course, using shareholders' money, and eventually sell at a decent profit in the future.Every business has its own strategy, but this shows us that holding isn’t necessarily the approach for every company.

comments.author: EFS
comments.body: If they invested in Bitcoin, made money and are now taking profits, good for them. They did the right thing and made profit. Nobody expects them to hold on to Bitcoin forever as Saylor says, they would've sold it eventually. I don't think this will create a butterfly effect and cause a wave of selling and start a bear market. If the price of Bitcoin goes down, they will buy it again, these types of funds don't approach financial instruments emotionally, they do what makes sense.

comments.author: Hazink
comments.body: They saw a massive profit and opportunity, and they took it, which is what the majority of investors will do. We have a different set of people who are into bitcoin; some of them are hodlers. You can't predict when they will sell; there is no profit that's considered enough for them, as it's as if they have a duration of a year they want to hold their bitcoin or they want to transfer it to their next generation. Some are holders using it as a means to escape inflation that could have affected their fiat if they had held their savings on it, so if they had a need for the fund, they would definitely sell. Meitu was just one of those companies that were looking for means to increase their revenue, which Bitcoin was the perfect option for, and once they got the profit they needed, they took it.

comments.author: nelson4lov
comments.body: Most companies that got into Bitcoin thus cycle will think that the cycle top is in just because we're at $100K which itself is an unexplored territory for Bitcoin so Meitu was just being careful but it shows how fearful they are and if Bitcoin does better than it's doing now, then they would have lost more potential profits just as German government sold bitcoin near the local bottom at the time.As I have always said, it's not every company that buys bitcoin will hold long term like Microstrategy. Let's not also forget that these firms owe it to their investors to deliver profits and selling is the major way they can realize the profit.
